
# Ostrich builtins

Here is a list of all Ostrich instructions and what they do. They are
arranged in ASCIIbetical order (the same order as in the source code).

*doc last autogenerated on Sat Jan 31 22:46:03 2015*

## `\n`, ` `

Whitespace is usually ignored in Ostrich, but be careful not to
accidentally assign to it!

    >>> {`...`+}: d;`wait` `what` `huh?`
    `wait...` `what...` `huh?`

## `!`

Logical not. `0`, ``` `` ```, `[]`, `{}` return `1`; everything else
returns `0`.

    >>> 0! ``! []! {}!
    1 1 1 1
    >>> ;;;; 1! ` `! [``]! {foo}!
    0 0 0 0

## `"`

Declares a single character literal. `"x` is shorthand for `` `x` ``.

    >>> "a "b "c
    `a` `b` `c`

## `#`

Array set.

## `$`

Sort, stack nth.

## `%`

TODO

## `&`

Bitwise/setwise and.

## `'`

Inspect.

## `(`

TODO

## `)`

TODO

## `*`

TODO

## `+`

TODO

## `,`

TODO

## `-`

TODO

## `.`

Duplicates the top element of the stack.

    >>> 1 2 . 3 4 . . 5 .
    1 2 2 3 4 4 4 5 5
    >>> ...6...
    1 2 2 3 4 4 4 5 5 5 5 5 6 6 6 6

## `/`

TODO

## `:`

Saves a value to a variable. (Does not remove the value from the stack!)

    >>> 42
    42
    >>> :a
    42
    >>> aaa
    42 42 42 42

## `;`

Removes the top element of the stack.

    >>> 42 0 1337
    42 0 1337
    >>> ;;
    42

## `<`

TODO

## `=`

TODO

## `>`

TODO

## `?`

TODO

## `@`

Roll stack.

## `A`

Absolute value.

## `B`

all ur base r belong to us

## `C`

Ceiling for numbers.

## `D`

Time since Unix epoch.

## `E`

Evaluate as Python code.

## `F`

Floor for numbers.

## `G`

Get a line of input.

## `H`

Head for arrays and strings (get the first element).

    >>> `foobar`H
    `f`
    >>> [1 2 3]H
    `f` 1

## `I`

If.

## `M`

Regex match.

## `P`

Print.

## `Q`

Quit the program.

## `R`

Generates a random number in the range [0, 1) (greater than or equal
to 0, and less than one).

    >>> R

## `S`

Read from STDIN.

## `T`

Tail for arrays and strings (get the last element).

    >>> `foobar`T
    `r`
    >>> [1 2 3]T
    `r` 3

## `V`

Divmod (pushes integer division and modulo result at the same time).

    >>> 10 3 V
    3 1

## `W`

Wrap the top `n` stack elements.

    >>> 1 2 3 4 5 3W
    1 2 [3 4 5]
    >>> 2W
    1 [2 [3 4 5]]
    >>> 6 7 8 1W
    1 [2 [3 4 5]] 6 7 [8]

## `X`

Regex replace.

## `Y`

Transliterate.

## `Z`

Zip.

## `[`

Array.

## `\`

Swap the top two stack elements.

    >>> 1 2 3 4 5 \
    1 2 3 5 4

## `]`

End array.

## `^`

Bitwise/setwise xor.

## `_`

Declares a single character block. `_x` is shorthand for `{x}`.

    >>> _a _b _c
    {a} {b} {c}

## `` ` ``

String.

## `{`

Block.

## `|`

Bitwise/setwise or.

## `}`

End block.

## `~`

Dump array, execute block/string, or negate number.
